Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: SusChEM: Polymers Derived from Vegetable Oils: Synthesis, Structure-Property Relationships and Sustainability
Award.AbstractNarration:
TECHNICAL SUMMARY:

The objective of this project is to address key scientific challenges enabling the broad implementation of triglyceride vegetable oils as an environmentally beneficial source for polymers with tunable physical properties. Vegetable oils are an attractive feedstock, based on their abundance, low cost, and ease of functionalization. This research plan is structured around four specific aims: design of synthetic techniques for vegetable oil-derived polymers, investigation of structure-property relationships in vegetable oil-derived polymers, development of biomass-derived nanostructured polymers for targeted applications, and assessment of the environmental impact of biomass-derived polymers. This approach will begin with synthetic strategies to modify the chemical structure of the polymers, employing metathesis chemistry and supramolecular interactions. A detailed understanding of structure-property-function relationships for these polymers will emphasize their thermal, mechanical, and rheological properties, targeting thermoplastic elastomers, stimuli-responsive and shape memory materials. Characterization of the thermodynamic interactions through spectroscopy and scattering experiments in the biorenewable polymers will allow for the a priori prediction of the nanoscale structure. Quantification of the environmental impacts of vegetable oil-derived polymers will guide future material design aspects, incorporating green engineering principles. The outcomes of the proposed work will provide a roadmap for the design of functional polymers from vegetable oils.

A number of major challenges will be addressed in this project. The bulky nature of the monomers may lead to synthetic challenges relative to their petroleum-derived counterparts and have key implications for the physical properties of the polymers. Biomass-derived materials may exhibit biodegradability and oxidative degradation. The presence of specific interactions may require looking beyond mean-field theories for modeling these polymers and their mixtures. Importantly, the structure-property-function relationships for these new materials are expected to be significantly different from those described in the vast body of literature for petroleum-derived polymers.



NON-TECHNICAL SUMMARY:

The world supply of petroleum is finite and in the future it will be necessary to utilize sustainable resources for the production of polymers. Polymers derived from agricultural sources offer benefits to society of enhanced biodegradability, reduced environmental impact, and utilization of an annually renewable resource. Replacements for commodity plastics have in many cases been successfully developed; however, relatively few studies have focused on biomass as a source for nanostructured materials. Polymers which exhibit nanoscale structure have tunable physical properties, which ultimately lead to important advances in material function. The proposed research will enable the implementation of polymers from a widely available agricultural source: vegetable oils. Additionally, this project will cultivate knowledge in students, educators and the general public on the relationships between energy, sustainability and the environmental impact of materials, through the broad participation of underrepresented groups in outreach programs, including women, Hispanic students and students from other minority groups. The following activities will be undertaken: a research-focused outreach program will be developed for local community college students; hands-on educational programs for students and teachers at targeted local high schools will be expanded; high school, undergraduate and graduate students will be mentored in the research project; and an exhibit will be designed for the Houston Museum of Natural Science on sustainable polymers.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The world supply of petroleum is finite and in the future it will be necessary to utilize sustainable sources for polymers. Polymers derived from agricultural sources offer benefits to society of reduced environmental impact, utilization of annually renewable resources, and, in some cases, enhanced biodegradability. The outcomes of this project enable the implementation of polymers from vegetable oils, widely available agricultural sources. Vegetable oils and their fatty acids are promising replacements for petroleum sources as polymer feedstocks due to their abundance, lack of toxicity and ease of functionalization. This project has focused on an important class of polymers: thermoplastic elastomers. These materials behave like rubber elastomers (with high degree of extensibility), yet, unlike rubber materials, have the ability to be processed into new products through high temperature processing, typically a characteristic associated with plastics. They have wide-reaching applications, such as in electronics, adhesives, automotive components, and road materials. Traditional thermoplastic elastomers are created from petroleum resources. In this work, fatty acid derivatives were used as the starting materials for creation of thermoplastic elastomers.

This project has addressed key scientific challenges in the use of vegetable oils and fatty acids as polymer feedstocks. Fatty acids are composed of long alkyl chains, and these chains have important implications for the resulting polymer properties. In the first phase of this project, the properties of fatty acid-based polymers were explored, in which the alkyl chain length (number of carbon atoms) of the fatty acid varied. The melting temperature and viscosity of the polymer were highly dependent on the alkyl chain length. Surprisingly, the alkyl chain length had no impact on the behavior of polymer mixtures containing the fatty acid-based polymers. These results are significant in that many important polymer properties (thermal, mechanical) can be manipulated through varying the fatty acid source of the polymer, and yet their mixing behavior with other polymers and blend morphology is unaffected.

In the next phase of the project, the fatty acid-based polymers were employed to create thermoplastic elastomers.  The thermoplastic elastomers were composed of ABA triblock copolymers, in which three disparate and incompatible polymers are covalently bonded together. The fatty acid-based polymer formed the midblock (B), and the endblocks (A) were composed of a glassy polymer (polystyrene, poly(methyl methacrylate), or sustainable polymers derived from rosins and phenolic acids). The hard A endblocks assembled within spheres, which were dispersed throughout the soft B matrix. The presence of this morphology was essential to the elastomeric behavior of the thermoplastic elastomers. The hard spheres were assembled into a close-packed arrangement; the existence of this morphology was attributed to the broad molecular weight distribution of the fatty acid-based midblock in the triblock copolymers. The mechanisms by which close-packed spheres formed under the application of shear were investigated using in situ techniques (scattering, rheology). The application of shear is relevant in industrial processes such as extrusion.  

The third phase of the project focused on the mechanical properties of the thermoplastic elastomers. A significant challenge was encountered as their strength and extensibility were inferior to that of traditional thermoplastic elastomers. The origin of this behavior was identified in the long alkyl chains of the fatty acids, which were incorporated into the polymers as alkyl side-chains off of the main polymer backbone. These alkyl side-chains prevented entanglement of the polymers within the thermoplastic elastomer matrix, reducing their mechanical properties. The polymers were engineered to contain specific interactions, either through hydrogen bonding or ionic interactions, in order to create chemical associations between polymer molecules, as replacements for physical entanglements. Significant improvements in both the strength and extensibility of the polymers were realized. These results demonstrate a viable route to creation of fatty acid-based polymers with desirable properties.

A concurrent project phase focused on the use of vegetable oil derivatives for modifying polylactide (PLA), a commercially available thermoplastic derived from plant sugars, which has applications in many consumer products and packaging. The widespread application of this material is limited by its brittleness. A multifunctional vegetable oil, acrylated epoxidized soybean oil (AESO), was investigated as an additive to improve the toughness of PLA. Mixtures of PLA and AESO exhibited an order of magnitude improvement in the elongation of break of the polymer and a factor of 6 improvement in the toughness. Evolution of the blend morphology was investigated through solvent casting and industrially-relevant melt mixing.

The results of this project were disseminated to broad communities, including K-12 students, undergraduate and graduate students, and the general public. Major activities included: (i) the Materials Day at UH program, organized by the PI, which showcased the importance of polymers and polymer sustainability to high school students; (ii) a collaboration with Houston Community College, in which the research results were presented through hands-on activities, and (iii) demonstrations for the general public at the Houston Energy Day and Earth Day festivals.


Last Modified: 01/03/2020
Modified by: Megan L Robertson
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: The world supply of petroleum is finite and in the future it will be necessary to utilize sustainable sources for polymers. Polymers derived from agricultural sources offer benefits to society of reduced environmental impact, utilization of annually renewable resources, and, in some cases, enhanced biodegradability. The outcomes of this project enable the implementation of polymers from vegetable oils, widely available agricultural sources. Vegetable oils and their fatty acids are promising replacements for petroleum sources as polymer feedstocks due to their abundance, lack of toxicity and ease of functionalization. This project has focused on an important class of polymers: thermoplastic elastomers. These materials behave like rubber elastomers (with high degree of extensibility), yet, unlike rubber materials, have the ability to be processed into new products through high temperature processing, typically a characteristic associated with plastics. They have wide-reaching applications, such as in electronics, adhesives, automotive components, and road materials. Traditional thermoplastic elastomers are created from petroleum resources. Evolution of the blend morphology was investigated through solvent casting and industrially-relevant melt mixing. The results of this project were disseminated to broad communities, including K-12 students, undergraduate and graduate students, and the general public. Major activities included: (i) the Materials Day at UH program, organized by the PI, which showcased the importance of polymers and polymer sustainability to high school students; (ii) a collaboration with Houston Community College, in which the research results were presented through hands-on activities, and (iii) demonstrations for the general public at the Houston Energy Day and Earth Day festivals.
